metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, this means only park-owned and managed devices such as kiosks, control panels, and security consoles can access essential networks and systems. related_mitre.explanation: Attackers might trick users into running malicious software on unmanaged devices that connect to the network.

content: Privileged users can perform administrative functions from devices that are not corporately managed.

metadata.principle: Principle B2 - Identity and Access Control
metadata.name: Privileged User Management
metadata.text: You closely manage privileged user access to networks and information systems supporting the essential function.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, privileged access to critical systems such as dinosaur enclosures, ticketing kiosks, and security networks is tightly controlled. metadata.name: Media / Equipment Sanitisation
metadata.text: Before reuse and / or disposal you appropriately sanitise devices, equipment and removable media holding data important to the operation of the essential function.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, this means ensuring that any kiosk systems, ticketing tablets, or removable drives used in operations are securely wiped or destroyed before being reused or discarded, to prevent leakage of sensitive ticketing or personal data.

related_mitre.name: Valid Accounts
related_mitre.explanation: Improper sanitisation may leave behind credentials or session data that attackers could exploit to access systems.

related_mitre.name: Disk Wipe
related_mitre.explanation: Adversaries may attempt to hide their activity or destroy evidence by wiping media; similarly, defenders must proactively wipe devices to prevent data leaks.

related_mitre.name: Hardware Additions
related_mitre.explanation: If sanitisation is incomplete, adversaries may retrieve data from disposed or repurposed hardware via physical access.

content: You have identified, documented and actively manage (e.g. maintain security configurations, patching, updating according to good practice) the assets that need to be carefully configured to maintain the security of the essential function.

metadata.name: Secure Configuration
metadata.text: You securely configure the network and information systems that support the operation of essential functions.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, this means documented and enforced secure configurations across all critical systems. The research center must have robust network security and hardened Active Directory configurations to prevent unauthorized access or privilege escalation. The park must avoid a single point of failure by managing administrator credentials carefully, ensuring no one person has uncontrolled access. Furthermore, ICS and IoT devices like electrical generators and dinosaur movement sensors must be securely configured and segmented from other networks to prevent manipulation or disruption.

related_mitre.name: Valid Accounts
related_mitre.explanation: The single system administrator with sole knowledge of passwords creates a risk where attackers could exploit valid accounts to gain unauthorized access.

related_mitre.name: Service Stop
related_mitre.explanation: Attackers could stop critical services such as electrical generators to cause outages and disrupt park operations.

related_mitre.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
related_mitre.explanation: Weak Active Directory and network configurations in the research center could allow attackers to escalate privileges.

related_mitre.name: Unauthorized Command Message
related_mitre.explanation: Manipulating commands to IoT devices like movement sensors could allow attackers to mislead the park's monitoring systems.

metadata.principle: Principle B5 - Resilient Networks and Systems
metadata.name: Design for Resilience
metadata.text: You design the network and information systems supporting your essential function to be resilient to cyber security incidents. Systems are appropriately segregated and resource limitations are mitigated.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, this means strictly segregating the ICS networks controlling electrical generators, dinosaur movement sensors, and containment systems from business and research networks. Operational systems must have no direct internet access to prevent external attacks. Redundancies in network paths and power supply ensure critical systems remain operational during failures or attacks. Geographic replication of backups and alternate connectivity paths mitigate natural disaster risks. Regular assessments ensure resilience measures adapt to evolving risks.

related_mitre.name: Valid Accounts
related_mitre.explanation: Segregation and strong access controls limit the abuse of valid credentials to move laterally across systems.

related_mitre.explanation: Network design mitigations reduce the impact of DoS attacks on critical operational systems.

related_mitre.explanation: Resilient design helps maintain essential services even under attack aiming to disrupt operations.

metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, this means strictly segregating the ICS networks controlling electrical generators, dinosaur movement sensors, and containment systems from business and research networks. Operational systems must have no direct internet access to prevent external attacks. Redundancies in network paths and power supply ensure critical systems remain operational during failures or attacks. Geographic replication of backups and alternate connectivity paths mitigate natural disaster risks. Regular assessments ensure resilience measures adapt to evolving risks.

related_mitre.name: Valid Accounts
related_mitre.explanation: Segregation and strong access controls limit the abuse of valid credentials to move laterally across systems.

related_mitre.name: Endpoint Denial of Service
related_mitre.explanation: Network design mitigations reduce the impact of DoS attacks on critical operational systems.

related_mitre.name: Service Stop
related_mitre.explanation: Resilient design helps maintain essential services even under attack aiming to disrupt operations.

content: You have appropriately secured backups (including data, configuration information, software, equipment, processes and knowledge). These backups will be accessible to recover from an extreme event.

metadata.principle: Principle B5 - Resilient Networks and Systems
metadata.name: Backups
metadata.text: You hold accessible and secured current backups of data and information needed to recover operation of your essential function.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, this means maintaining secure, regularly tested backups of all critical data and configurationsâ€”including research data, Active Directory credentials, ICS device settings for generators and dinosaur sensors, and operational procedures. Backups are stored offsite or in secure secondary locations to enable recovery after extreme events such as natural disasters or ransomware attacks. Regular tests ensure backups are usable and restoration processes are reliable, preventing operational paralysis even if the single system administrator is unavailable.

related_mitre.name: Valid Accounts
related_mitre.explanation: Protecting backup credentials helps prevent attackers from abusing valid accounts to disrupt recovery.

related_mitre.explanation: Backups provide recovery options if ransomware encrypts operational data.

related_mitre.name: Data from Local System
related_mitre.explanation: Attackers may target local backup files, so securing backup storage is essential.

metadata.principle: Principle B6 - Staff Awareness and Training
metadata.name: Cyber Security Culture
metadata.text: You develop and maintain a positive cyber security culture.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, all staffâ€”ranging from the system administrator, researchers, maintenance teams, to security personnelâ€”are trained and encouraged to understand their role in cyber security. Management actively promotes open communication, where reporting cyber incidents or suspicious activity is welcomed and rewarded without fear. This helps prevent incidents caused by social engineering, insider threats, or neglect. Training includes recognizing phishing, securing valid accounts, and reporting unusual system behavior.

related_mitre.name: Phishing
related_mitre.explanation: Educated staff are more likely to detect and report phishing attempts.

related_mitre.name: Service Stop
related_mitre.explanation: Timely reporting can help mitigate denial of service or disruption attacks.

metadata.text: The people who support the operation of your essential function are appropriately trained in cyber security. A range of approaches to cyber security training, awareness and communications are employed.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, all staffâ€”from researchers managing critical lab data, maintenance teams handling generators and sensors, to the system administratorâ€”receive regular, role-specific cyber security training. related_mitre.name: Masquerading
related_mitre.explanation: Training raises awareness about techniques used to disguise malicious activities or software.

metadata.text: The people who support the operation of your essential function are appropriately trained in cyber security. A range of approaches to cyber security training, awareness and communications are employed.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, all staffâ€”from researchers managing critical lab data, maintenance teams handling generators and sensors, to the system administratorâ€”receive regular, role-specific cyber security training. Training covers securing accounts, recognizing phishing and social engineering attempts, and maintaining operational security. Multiple training formats ensure accessibility, with progress tracked and training refreshed to keep security awareness high, mitigating risks like credential abuse and insider threats.

content: Monitoring is based on an understanding of your networks, common cyber attack methods and what you need awareness of in order to detect potential security incidents that could affect the operation of your essential function (e.g. presence of malware, malicious emails, user policy violations).

metadata.name: Monitoring Coverage
metadata.text: The data sources that you include in your monitoring allow for timely identification of security events which might affect the operation of your essential function.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, this means comprehensive monitoring of network traffic between the research center, operational control systems like electrical generators and dinosaur sensors, and external connections. Host-based monitoring captures logs from Active Directory, research databases, and control devices. User activities, particularly those of the single system administrator and other privileged accounts, are closely audited for suspicious behavior. All IoT sensors and new devices are integrated into the monitoring system to detect malware, command and control traffic, and policy violations swiftly, ensuring quick response to security incidents.

content: The integrity of logging data is protected, or any modification is detected and attributed.

metadata.name: Securing Logs
metadata.text: You hold logging data securely and grant read access only to accounts with business need. No employee should ever need to modify or delete logging data within an agreed retention period, after which it should be deleted.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, this means all logs from critical systems including Active Directory, network infrastructure, IoT sensors monitoring dinosaur movements, electrical generators, and research systems are securely stored in tamper-evident repositories. Only authorised personnel can read logs, with no ability to modify or delete them until the retention period expires. Access to logs is fully audited and attributable, with strict policies governing legitimate use. Accurate time synchronization enables correlation of events across systems to detect and investigate incidents effectively.

related_mitre.name: Valid Accounts
related_mitre.explanation: Ensuring only authorized users can access logs prevents attackers abusing stolen credentials to erase traces.

related_mitre.name: Email Collection
related_mitre.explanation: Monitoring logs can help detect data exfiltration attempts via email.

related_mitre.name: Indicator Removal
related_mitre.explanation: Prevents attackers from deleting or tampering with logs to cover their tracks.

content: The logging architecture has mechanisms, processes and procedures to ensure that it can protect itself from threats comparable to those it is trying to identify. This includes protecting the function itself, and the data within it.

metadata.text: You hold logging data securely and grant read access only to accounts with business need. No employee should ever need to modify or delete logging data within an agreed retention period, after which it should be deleted.

metadata.text: You have the capability to enact your incident response plan, including effective limitation of impact on the operation of your essential function. During an incident, you have access to timely information on which to base your response decisions.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park,  this means regularly testing and exercising incident response plans focused on ticketing systems at kiosks and online bookings, ensuring staff have access to timely information and clear communication channels during incidents to limit impact and restore services efficiently.

related_mitre.name: Service Stop
related_mitre.explanation: Attackers may attempt to stop essential services; response capabilities need to address service restoration.

related_mitre.name: Container Administration Command
related_mitre.explanation: Use of administrative commands during recovery or containment actions.

related_mitre.name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution
related_mitre.explanation: Recovery processes may include addressing persistence mechanisms.

content: During incidents you have timely information and structured decision-making processes to support response and recovery actions.

metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, this means regularly running incident response exercises focused on scenarios such as ticket system outages or data breaches at kiosks and online bookings, ensuring lessons learned are applied to improve security and recovery plans.

related_mitre.explanation: Testing detection and response to command-line or scripting-based attacks during exercises.

content: Exercise scenarios are documented, regularly reviewed, and validated.

metadata.name: Incident Root Cause Analysis
metadata.text: When an incident occurs, steps must be taken to understand its root causes and ensure appropriate remediating action is taken.
metadata.contextualized_to_park: In Cyberland Park, this means thoroughly investigating incidents involving ticketing systems and kiosks to identify root causes such as misconfigurations, credential misuse, or software vulnerabilities, and applying fixes to prevent recurrence.

related_mitre.name: Valid Accounts
related_mitre.explanation: Weak account policies at kiosks could allow attackers to abuse valid credentials.

related_mitre.name: Data Manipulation
related_mitre.explanation: Attackers may manipulate ticketing or booking data, requiring root cause analysis to identify how this occurred.

related_mitre.name: System Information Discovery
related_mitre.explanation: Understanding system configurations and information can help in root cause analysis of incidents.

content: Your root cause analysis is comprehensive, covering organisational process issues, as well as vulnerabilities in your networks, systems or software.

metadata.name: Using Incidents to Drive Improvements
metadata.text: Your organisation uses lessons learned from incidents to improve your security measures.
